I mean, if we can agree that the tendency of safe districts to produce ideologues with no personal incentive to compromise is a primary reason for the ineffectiveness of our current Congress, term limits only make the problem worse.  Even if they don’t feel pressure to protect their tenure, candidates – professional politician or not -- have to please voters and donors in order to be elected in the first place.  In a system of safe districts term limits only reinforce the tendency to favor ideological rigidity because they remove the counterbalancing pressure to demonstrate effectiveness over time, if effectiveness means anything more than trumpeting supporters’ views.
Besides, if a candidate is in it for self-enrichment, retirement from office is the big payoff, not election, since it frees one to openly fall into the bejeweled embrace of a lobbying firm.

Some believe that the problem with Congress is Congress -- that by its nature the institution corrupts blowhards into statespeople -- and so they argue for term limits.  It makes sense if you accept the premise.  But people who want an effective Congress should not favor term limits which don't free politicians from political pressure but instead relieve them of the burden of proving themselves to be effective legislators.

Number of months ago, I attended an enlightening lecture by a NOAA scientist. Here's the science, 25% of the CO2 that goes in the air gets absorbed by the Ocean. Rising CO2 causes the Ocean to become more acidic. CO2).http://www.pmel.noaa.gov/co2/story/Ocean+Acidification.

Twenty years ago marine biologists began seeing problems with marine life like coral reefs dying. This isn't to say high levels of CO2 haven't affected sea life historically, the problem we have today is the shift in acidity or PH is happening at such a fast rate life can't adjust. The CO2 levels have pushed the acidity of the Ocean to a level where the shells required by larval (baby) marine life is dissolving. This means that the bottom of the Ocean's food chain is dying. Off our coast, there is a small snail that makes up 50% of a juvenile salmon's food intake. These snails swim up over 300 feet to feed at the surface at night. Because the CO2 levels have risen so rapidly the effect of the CO2 acidification is concentrated in the top layer of the Ocean, most marine life is in the top 150 feet. When the shells of these snails dissolves they die and with that the salmon's food disappears.

I've illustrated a single case for salmon unless we reverse the CO2 levels the food chain of the entire Ocean will collapse. I personally don’t want that to happen to future generations and I’d question the sanity or moral fiber of anyone that does.

Dale, there are a series of misleading statements in your claims which are sufficiently egregious that they make me wonder whether they are in good faith.

"CO2.... where shellfish use it to make their armor."

This is nonsense, and you know it. Shells are made from Calcium Carbonate, it is the calcium which is limiting, CO2 disassociates in water to produce carbonic acid; the shift in carbonic acid is making it increasingly difficult for many calciferous species.

Papers "which calculate that the residence time..." read those papers again; either you fail to comprehend them, or you are intentionally misrepresenting their import. You attempt to claim that if mankind stopped producing CO2 the atmospheric CO2 concentration would return to the pre-industrial value by an exponential process with a time-constant of about 7 years ... the authors of the papers you cite said nothing of the sort.

Lee,

Don't assign to malice what might just be incompetence (or a defective sense of humor). For the anonymous, malice must be presumed from the beginning though.

Dr. Pierrehumbert has done us a great service by putting in perspective the small effect of methane on potential global warming.

I hope he will next turn his formidable intellect on to the topic of the residence time of CO2 in the atmosphere, which he says above that methane is short-lived in the atmosphere "...compared to CO2, which basically hangs around forever."

CO2 is not an inert gas like argon. It is soluble in water. It is taken up by all plant matter to make their leaves and stems. Rainwater sweeps it into the ocean where shellfish use it to make their armor. it forms carbonate and bicarbonate ions in the ocean, is precipitated as calcium carbonate and sequestered for geologic time in rock.

I have on my lap a list of 36 references from the mainstream scientific literature, too long to list individually, but dating from 1957 to 1992, before climate science was politicized, which calculate that the residence time of CO2 in the atmosphere ranges from 2 to 25 years. The average estimate is about 7 years, plus or minus 3.

This is not "forever".

See, please, Segalstand 1997 and Sunguist 1985.

And yes, I have read Archer's work stating that CO2 persists for 2000 years in the atmosphere.

Codswallop.

Dr. Pierrehumbert asserts that emissions of methane are reversible.

If so, then emissions of CO2, which is much more reactive in aqueous solution than methane, are also reversible and even more so than methane.

I have always found it curious and worth remembering that the 'Zeus' in the genitives case is 'Dios.' English uses a Germanic name for character with similar attributes.

Dionysos -- the Zeus of Turkey's Mount Nysa -- died each fall, was buried in the sanctuary of Apollo at Delphi, which he would abandon until Dionysos'' rebirth in the spring. "He is risen," his believers cried out on the appropriate Sunday sunrise, and Apollo had returned.

The great advances of Greek civilization in the fifth and fourth centuries began quite suddenty when the sophists, whom Plato and Socrates despised, stripped the gods out of the myths. That left them with only the natural phenomena the gods were thought to personify and control. So much for the supernatural. The pagan Greeks made no sharp distinction between nature and any hyper-nature, though it is easy for us to see them edging towards it. Christianity defined the boundary.

Professor Gutting blurs a different line, the line between an experience and one's interpretation of the experience. The Greek Pantheon provided a flea market full of interpretations for the asking. It is a curious thing, though it may not remain so for much longer, that neurologists cannot yet distinguish between brain states that are active when dealing with knowledge and when dealing with beliefs, though we all make that distinction ourselves (if not always consistently).

Gutting failed to discuss ritual as an intrinsic leaven in their beliefs.

At 50 and a normal healthy weight, I herniated the disc between L4 & L5 and developed sciatica. Required 4 days of hospitalization and 6 weeks in a back brace. My "excellent" western-medicine trained Boston orthopedist gave me a pharmacopeia of narcotic pain meds and recommended cortisone injections. This bad medicine went on for 2 1/2 years, as the back pain and sciatica returned 4 months after each injection and I only took the pain killers at night because they made me too stoned to think. This brilliant doctor told me to start jogging.

Finally, I took my health recovery into my own hands. I demanded referral to physical therapy and chiropractic, and stopped the narcotic pain meds and injections a year ago. I found a wonderful physical therapist who is also a licensed Stott method Pilates instructor. She transitioned me from PT to Stott Pilates (mat work) and aqua therapy PT.

I'm now 53. I haven't had an injection in a year. I have NO pain. I've lost an entire dress size and I look great. I do Pilates at home every day and one class a week with this PT, plus 1 hour of independent outpatient aqua therapy at a PT pool. It costs less than my insurance co-pays. I go to the chiropractor every 3 weeks. I also bought an inversion table and I stretch at a 45 degree incline for 10 minutes 3x/week. I have improved my core and back muscle strength.

My brilliant Boston orthopedist never told me about any of this.

A shill speaks for Summers. As a Harvard grad and Cambridge resident during Summer's tenure, I saw him drive the University's endowment and capital improvement plan into the dirt. He left Allston Mass high and dry where it now is being turned into a corporate playground.

As I recall (not being a financial expert) Summer's main gamble came with parlaying an investment "bet" using the University's cash on hand, rather than any investment strategy with portfolio. So when this "bet" tanked, which it did 100%, the University was left without any cash to fund its basic operations. It suffered the first round of strategic layoffs I believe in its history, had to ditch the Allston plan, and day to day operations suffered significantly.

The one comment I recall came from Stanford's main investment officer. She said she had never sen anyone take a risk like that before. I believe she said (or maybe this is my creative interpretation), that he gambled their lunch money, Sadly, Harvard went hungry for quite some time. There is still a gaping hole in the ground across the Charles River from the main campus and a lot of animosity on the part of that city's residents towards its non-tax paying neighbor.

Reckless, irresponsible, stubborn and tone deaf are all words I would associate with Lawrence Summers.

"They try to tax the consumers, by limiting their choices. And they try to tax the authors, by limiting their choices."

This is nonsensical. A tax is a coercive extraction of funds. Any consumer who does not wish to purchase a book is free to abstain from doing.

No producer is a slave, obliged against his will to do the bidding of anyone in order to "increase the choices" available to that other person. Authors have more ways than ever to be published today, including self-publication via ebooks. In this context, it is worse than contradictory to say that authors are being "taxed" by contract terms between two other parties that an author may not like.

It's the DOJ and its supporters who are advocating, and in the government's case, using actual coercion to interfere with the judgment and choices of Apple and publishers as they voluntarily contract with each other. They don't owe anybody else anything except the same thing that you, the critic, owe to Apple and the publishers: respect for their rights to conduct their lives and businesses as they see fit, so long as they do so peacefully. But the distinction between physical force and voluntary transactions does not exist in the minds of many of the DOJ's supporters.
